23. 
Instructions', the incidents of this unfortunate period. 
Should an opinion be advanced that Dr Shaw's 
remarks need not carry the interpretation I have placed 
on them, I must venture to remind you that this is 
rightfully gauged by the effect they have produced in 
the public mind. 
The publication of this volume was quickly <s>f<\s> 
followed by a review which appeared in the Supplement of 
the Times of August 13th. 
That review undeniably and most seriously 
reflects on me, my Officers and those responsible for 
the organization of the Expedition and yet it would be 
impossible to contend that the reviewer has drawn any 
but legitimate inferences from the pages of the volume. 
Under these circumstances I am justified in 
asking that the matter shall be officially investigated, 
that inaccurate statements shall be withdrawn as publicly 
as they were made, and that some explanation shall be 
given why neither I nor any member of the Expedition was 
shown the results of our work before they were made public. 
Surely this last omission must be altogether unprecedented. 

I remain, 
Yours sincerely, 

R.Scott 
captain R.N. 

Sir Archibald Geikie 
K.C.B. etc. 
Secretary to the Royal Society
